title: Exploring Earth and Environmental Sciences
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESSC1000.
description: (UGEB1870 is double-coded with EESC1001.) The course provides an interdisciplinary study of the Earth Systems, including natural phenomena in the atmosphere, hydrosphere, geosphere, cryosphere, and biosphere. The mechanism of these systems, associated dynamics and anthropogenic impacts will be introduced and discussed. The course also serves as a platform to understand and critically assess global environmental change, natural hazards, biodiversity loss, and the water-energy-food nexus, and explore potential technological and policy solutions to these problems. These objectives align strongly with the understanding and pursuit of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, especially SDG#7 Affordable and Clean Energy, SDG#13 Climate Action, SDG#14 Life Below Water, and SDG#15 Life on Land. In addition to attending lectures, students will visit the Jockey Club Museum of Climate Change where it displays the way scientists examine past and current climate and the factors leading to current global temperature change. A geological field excursion will be another highlight of the course to demonstrate the scientific concepts applied to reveal Earth’s tectonic history, evolution and interaction among various spheres. With diverse scientific topics in Earth’s systems, the course shows students how each Earth’s system is interlocking with other spheres and, hence raise the awareness in the importance of sustainability.
outcome: Describe and explain how the atmosphere, hydrosphere, geosphere, cryosphere, and biosphere interact and how feedback mechanisms operate among the Earth systems.  Develop an interdisciplinary approach for investigating Earth system dynamics.   Discuss the anthropogenic influences, as well as scientific and technical challenges related to global environmental changes, natural hazards, and the food-water-energy nexus critically.  Recognize the complexity of linkages between environmental pressures and human responses related to contemporary sustainable development challenges, contributing to the understanding and pursuit of SDG#7 Affordable and Clean Energy, SDG#13 Climate Action, SDG#14 Life below Water, and SDG#15 Life on Land.  Communicate effectively about Earth system and environmental issues in an appropriate science format (i.e. scientific poster and QnA) through working independently and collaboratively.

Visit: To show students how professional field works to understand our Earth  Field trip: To facilitate students observe the environment and interpret and discuss related environmental problems   Note: Students are expected to attend all lectures, and participate in all tutorials, the visit and the field trip. Students will be introduced to the solid physical foundations of the solid Earth, as well as an overview of the structure and composition of the Earth, its materials and constituents, dynamics of its internal and external processes.     Part II: Atmosphere and Climate (Week 7-9)  This compenent covers an integrated introduction to the climate system and the dynamics and chemistry of the atmosphere. title: Introductory Practical Course in Earth and Environmental Sciences
description: The Introductory Practical Course in Earth and Environmental Sciences is a project-based learning experience designed to introduce freshmen to Earth and Environmental Sciences through direct field observation and hands-on project work. This course will be led by 3 instructors in Geology and Geophysics, Atmospheric Sciences and Environmental Sciences. By exploring the geology beneath our feet, the atmospheric currents above us, and the environmental issues that surround us, students will gain a holistic understanding of our planet.
outcome: 1. Introduction to Hong Kong Geology: Able to read the basic information from a geological map Gain a brief understanding in major rock types in Hong Kong  Understanding the geological history of Hong Kong Able to correlate the map information, outcrop properties and the landscape 2. Atmospheric Science - Earth’s Rotation and Weather: Describe the basic principles of Earth's rotation and the Coriolis effect and their influence on global weather patterns. Evaluate the impact of the Coriolis effect on weather systems, including the rotation of tropical cyclones, using meteorological data. Design and conduct laboratory experiments to apply theoretical knowledge of atmospheric science to simulate and analyze real-world weather phenomena. 3. Environmental Science - Water Quality: Summarize the key indicators of water quality and discuss their implications for ecosystem health and human well-being. Design and perform experiments to collect and assess water samples, measuring parameters such as pH, turbidity, and pollutants to determine water quality. Assess the sources and consequences of water pollution and propose viable solutions for improving water quality based on scientific evidence.
syllabus: Introduction to Hong Kong Geology: This field study takes students to a geologically interesting field area in Hong Kong, providing an outdoor classroom to understand geological processes. Students will learn practical field skills in identifying the rocks, reading geological maps, and understanding how the Earth’s processes shape the landscape.  Atmospheric Science - Earth’s Rotation and Weather: This part is designed to introduce students to the fundamental concepts of Earth's rotation and the Coriolis effect, and their impact on our weather such as the rotation of tropical cyclones. Through a combination of theoretical lectures and laboratory experiments, students will gain a comprehensive understanding of these phenomena.   Environmental Science - Water Quality: This practical study immerses students in the field of environmental science with a focus on water quality. Students will collect and analyze water samples from various sources, testing for parameters like pH, turbidity, and presence of pollutants. This project will underscore the importance of clean, healthy water for ecosystems and human societies, illustrating environmental challenges and potential solutions.

description: EESC2009 is a fundamental field-based course introducing elementary concepts of past Earth’s processes and environmental changes. It also covers important aspects of plate tectonics, different rock types, geological deformation, geomorphology and environmental changes, natural hazards and human impacts. The principal goal of this course is to let students understand how the present geological records and landforms reveal the past tectonic movements and affect the human urban planning. Students are trained to observe, describe and discuss field features, with the help of field tools (e.g. compasses-clinometer and GPS receiver). Basic skills of field techniques, interpreting geologic maps and making field notes are introduced to assist students acquiring field data and discuss possible geologic processes. A field report from each group is required to summarize the field study logically. Field locations of this course may change from year to year. All students are welcome, but priority will be given to students who have taken EESC1001.

title: Solid Earth Dynamics
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESSC2010.
description: This course presents an integrated introduction to the solid earth system stressing the geological, chemical, physical, and biological interactions among the lithosphere, hydrosphere and cryosphere. The course applies basic scientific and mathematical concepts to explain the history and behaviour of the solid earth system. Geophysical and geochemical techniques for probing the interior of the earth are reviewed. Plate tectonics is introduced as a unifying theme to understand geodynamic processes. The course includes discussions of topics that are relevant to society, resources and sustainability, such as the physical and chemical basis of natural hazards (earthquakes, tsunami, landslides) and their mitigation, and the impact of geological processes on the global environment.
outcome: This course will contribute to the understanding of the dynamics of the solid Earth system, specifically the lithosphere, hydrosphere and cryosphere, as well as their interaction. The students should be able to: 1) describe and use the scientific process, explain how theories are built upon earth system observations, and how both are tested and revised; 2) explain how fundamental physical, chemical, and biological principles govern specific earth system processes; 3) participate knowledgeably and intelligently in discussions of public policy related to earth system science, particularly with respect to natural hazards, resources, environment and sustainable development; 4) work effectively in a team, and present information in a clear, concise and logical manner.

title: Climate System Dynamics
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESSC2020.

Topics include Earth’s energy balance, climate feedback, convection and clouds, general circulation of the atmosphere and ocean, biogeochemistry and global carbon cycle, roles of vegetation and ecosystems, and historical and future climate change. Student taking this course are expected to have taken PHYS1111, CHEM1070 and MATH1010 or equivalent.

title: Intermediate Geosciences Field Study II
requirements: Pre-requisite: (EESC2010 or ESSC2010) and with instructor's approval.
description: EESC2129 is designed to provide students with fundamental geological field techniques and the application of geological and environmental concepts specific to the region of Hong Kong. The course aims to deepen students' understanding of the local geology, including its formation processes, tectonic history, and its relationship with the environment. By the end of the course, students will have acquired a solid background in local geology and geomorphology. The course emphasizes hands-on training and practical skills development. Students will learn essential geological field techniques, including map reading, gathering geological data, making field observations, and jotting geological field notes. They will also develop critical thinking skills through the analysis and interpretation of geological data. Additionally, the course includes training in life-saving skills to ensure students' safety during fieldwork. EESC2129 consists of a 10-day local field study and five pre-trip lectures. The field study provides an immersive experience where students will directly apply the knowledge and techniques learned in the classroom to real geological settings in Hong Kong. The pre-trip lectures serve as a preparatory phase, covering relevant theoretical concepts, field methodologies, and safety protocols. Following the field study, two post-trip discussions will provide an opportunity for students to share their findings, and engage in further analysis and interpretation. Successful completion of EESC2129 requires continuous teamwork and independent assignments. Students will be expected to collaborate with their peers during fieldwork, share responsibilities, and contribute to group discussions. Additionally, independent assignments will be assigned to reinforce students' understanding of the course material and encourage individual exploration of specific geological topics.Note: This course may involve physical activities and fieldwork in outdoor environments. Students are advised to comply with safety guidelines, follow instructions from instructors, and maintain appropriate fitness levels to ensure a safe and enriching learning experience.
outcome: Students are expected to gain the following abilities: Understanding Hong Kong’s fundamental geological history, lithology, structures, mineral forming processes and landforms. Studying different local lithological units (including sedimentary, metamorphic, igneous rocks) in the field. Using field equipment, such as geological compasses, to acquire field data. Producing geological field notes. Discussing and analysing the field observation critically based on evidence and scientific principle. Summarizing information in a clear, concise and logical manner in the field notes and group reports to understand geologic processes, paleo-environments and present geomorphology. Working independently and self-study. Work in a team and discuss with teammates.

title: Minerals and Natural Resources
requirements: Pre-requisite: EESC2010 or ESSC2010
description: EESC2160 is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of minerals as fundamental building blocks of the Earth, their chemistry, occurrence, physical and chemical features, crystallography, as well as the formation and uses of naturally formed minerals, oil, and gas. The course also covers mining processes and management, exploring the interaction between natural resources and the environment, and their impact on the biological system. The course teaches students chemistry in the Solid Earth, occurrence, exploration and usage of natural resources like minerals, gas and oil. The course trains students with skills of identifying physical properties and chemical properties of natural forming minerals. Teachers will introduce techniques and technology in mining and extracting natural resources. Areas of interaction between natural resources and the environment, as well as the management of natural resources, will be elaborated in student’s problem-based learning sessions. Students are expected to equip knowledge and skills in understanding the real-world scenarios of the natural resources, and problem-solving skills in resource management practices and decision-making processes.
outcome: Upon completing this course, students will be able to: Describe the rock-forming minerals in terms of their chemistry, structural characteristics, and physical properties. title: Elementary Methods for Earth and Environmental Sciences
requirements: Pre-requisite: (MATH1520 or MATH1010) or permission of instructor.
description: The course provides a survey of elementary analytical quantitative and qualitative methods commonly used in earth and environmental sciences, with applications in geophysics, geophysical/environmental fluid dynamics, as well as related aspects in thermodynamics and wave physics. Teaching aided by numerical programming is adopted and emphasized, in addition to analytical understanding of these methods. Typical examples include heat conduction on earth surface, seismic and ocean waves, air pollution, geodynamics, and atmospheric dynamics.

Rayleigh wave as surface wave; 2-D waves versus 3-D waves; Analysis of seismic signals using Fourier transforms, physical meaning of phase shift, physical meaning of Fourier transform magnitude. title: Global Environmental Change
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESSC3800.
description: This course includes the science behind the global warming issue, how the public views the issue and the critical thinking needed to analyze the evidence seen in the media/articles from the point of view of scientists. The world energy use, which is considered to be the cause of global warming, and the impacts are discussed in the course. In this course, students will learn about the radiation budgets/balance in the atmosphere, possible climate forcings that can upset the energy balance, how the earth’s global average temperature is measured, why global warming is described as “the biggest hoax” in human history, observations from the ocean and cryosphere and popular environmental issues/arguments discussed in the mainstream media. Newest observations from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report are included throughout the course.This course actively incorporates elements of innovation, design, global citizenship and social enterprisingness by asking the students to think innovatively but critically about possible solutions to adapt to and combat climate change and the global energy/health crisis. Different options including their pros and cons are actively discussed in class. Students are encouraged to think creatively about the problem from different angles, e.g., by standing in the shoes of climate skeptics – evaluating their “data”, how they present them, the arguments put forth by them – in order to develop a strategic approach to best communicate the issues to a variety of stakeholders. Project assignments will allow students to focus on one particular environmental issue in other part of the world, attempting to address the issue in the very different geographical, cultural, economic and political contexts from that of the students. Example projects can be “How to use geoengineering to combat climate change?”, “How can Sub-Saharan Africa secure its future food supply under the threat of climate change?”, etc. In the course, students will define and understand the problem. They shall form groups and discuss their own point of views and search information on the evidence of the corresponding arguments. They will present their ideas in class and write a self-reflection report. Each of the group will have to make an “infographic”- a layout of science knowledge learnt in the project that is easy enough for the public to understand but at the same time informative. description: Understanding Earth processes and environmental changes over geological time requires the experience and skills gained from fieldwork. EESC4119 is an advanced-level course of the Earth and Environmental Sciences Programme. It covers important aspects of field geology, including petrology, structural geology, tectonics, geophysics, and surficial processes. The principal goal of this course is to train students to recognize different lithological units and their spatial relationship in three dimensions, and to understand the related tectonic environment and formation mechanisms. Class lectures introduce basic skills of reading and interpreting geological maps, using geological equipment (i.e., compass-clinometer, GPS receiver), and producing field notes and reports. Field projects include field observation and description, techniques for field data acquisition and analysis, sample collection, and geological map compilation. Field projects also focus on surficial processes, which occur over relatively short geological timescales but play important roles in environment and ecology. The field location, whether in mainland China or overseas, may change from year to year.

title: Petrology
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESSC4120. Pre-requisite: EESC2010 or ESSC2010.
description: Petrology is an essential subfield of Earth and Environmental Sciences because the rock record is the foundation for interpreting Earth history and internal processes. Petrologic concepts help us understand the Earth system, with connections to related fields such as geochemistry, geophysics, mineralogy, structural geology and geodynamics. This course broadly surveys the formation, distribution, chemical composition, mineral associations, and internal texture and structures in rocks of the earth’s crust and upper mantle, and establishes it relation to global tectonic environments. Class lectures are supplemented by lab exercise, demonstrations and tutorials (e.g. study of rock hand specimens, understand phase rule, use of optical microscope etc.).

description: EESC4129 is a comprehensive course designed to provide students with a deep understanding of plate tectonics, advanced geological field techniques, and their applications in engineering and water resources. The course aims to introduce students to the fundamental concepts of plate tectonics, including sea floor spreading, subduction, and mineral deposits. Additionally, it focuses on teaching students advanced geological field techniques and their practical application in field studies. The course also addresses engineering problems related to geological factors and explores the significance of water resources within a geological context. EESC4129 incorporates a combination of theoretical knowledge and practical training. The course includes 10 lectures covering essential concepts and techniques, plus 14 days in the field and engage in onsite discussions. Students will have the opportunity to visit a geologically significant area to gain firsthand experience and understanding of the geological setting, formation processes, tectonic history, and their relationship with urban planning. This field study will provide students with a solid background in local geology and geomorphology, enabling them to comprehend the geological processes and their implications in various settings. Students will engage in a mapping exercise, where they will collect geological data, perform detailed field observations, and analyze their findings. This exercise will enhance their critical thinking skills and equip them with the ability to plan geological projects effectively. Additionally, students will receive training in life-saving skills to ensure their safety during fieldwork. By the end of the course, students will have developed a heightened awareness of the interplay between geology and urban planning, contributing to their holistic understanding of the natural environment.

title: Volcanoes
description: On any given day, ~20 subaerial volcanoes worldwide are erupting. Even more submarine volcanoes are probably erupting without being detected. Volcanic eruptions can have devastating economic and social consequences, but are also the fundamental force that builds the majority of our planet’s surface. Volcanic eruptions and emissions can also affect atmospheric and climate conditions. This course will explore the various techniques used to study volcanoes’ underlying structure as well as their precursory and eruptive activity.

requirements: Not for students who have taken ESSC4250. Pre-requisite: EESC3200 or ESSC3200 or permission of instructor.

title: Urban Climatology
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESSC4260. Pre-requisite: EESC2020 or ESSC2020.
description: Human modifications to the surface of the Earth during urbanisation change most of the elements of climate and weather in the urban atmosphere. This course introduces the fundamentals of urban climatology and the processes caused by the changes in the surface environment, particularly focusing on how urban structures interact with the atmospheric environment. Numerical modelling and field techniques are introduced to understand the underlying processes resulting urban climatic phenomena. It also examines the implications on human comfort and climate-sensitive urban planning and design, as well as the relationship between cities and climate change

title: Cloud Dynamics
requirements: Pre-requisite: EESC2020 or ESSC2020.
description: This course presents an introduction to the science of clouds. We begin with a descriptive cloud classification to introduce the different types of clouds in the Earth’s atmosphere. The roles of aerosols in cloud are also discussed. This is followed by cloud microphysics, describing the basic microphysical processes regarding formation, growth, shrinkage, breakup and fallout of cloud and precipitation particles. Next, different structures of precipitation and radar cloud sensing are presented. This will then be linked to cloud dynamics, associated with the fluid motions of the atmosphere. Student taking this course are expected to have taken EESC2020 or ESSC2020.
outcome: Students shall learn about a wide variety of physics and dynamics that control the occurrence, characteristics, and behavior of clouds. They shall understand the processes determining all the types of clouds in our atmosphere, over a wide range of spatial scales from microns to thousands of kilometers. They shall appreciate the importance of cloud to Earth’s climate. There are also be opportunities (e.g. outdoor cloud observation, cloud dynamics practicals both computationally and experimentally) where student can practice working effectively in a team, and present information in a clear, concise and logical manner.

title: Practical Atmospheric Modeling
requirements: Pre-requisite: (EESC2020 or ESSC2020) and (MATH2550 or EESC2520 or PHYS2051) and (PHYS1001 or 1002 or 1111 or 1113), or permission of instructor.
description: This course introduces the basic principles of atmospheric modeling and provides hands-on practice to perform numerical simulations on University computing cluster. It begins with the concept of model and reviewing of physical and chemical processes in the atmosphere. After that, this course will cover introduction and hands-on practice of the three basic processes in atmospheric simulation: pre-processing data, modeling, and post-processing data. The pre-processing process refers to the preparation of data from various sources by different techniques such as the generation of emission inventories for atmospheric chemistry modeling. It then introduces numerical modeling basics such as “model equations and numerical approaches”. For post-processing, this course offers different skills in visualization of the model output and evaluation of model output against real-world observations. This course also introduces advanced knowledge in “model coupling” and “inverse modeling”. Finally, this course provides hands-on practice on simple model development experiments. During the course, we will cover basic Linux environment commands to perform the main tasks mentioned above. Overall, students can anticipate grasping basic modeling concepts and skills from this course, which are of great value to their future careers in both academia and industry.
outcome: Remember and explain the major chemical and physical processes that affect spatiotemporal variations of major atmospheric composition. Explain the basic framework of atmospheric chemistry models including their input and output. Understand what an emission inventory is and be able to pre-process emission inventory for atmospheric chemistry models. Able to compile and run an atmospheric chemistry model. Capable of visualizing model outputs and evaluating model outputs against observations. Have the skills to sort out model structure by reading model codes and then revise model codes according to research needs.

Volcanic eruptions and emissions can also affect atmospheric and climate conditions. title: Tropical Meteorology

description: This course introduces tropical atmospheric circulation and related air-sea coupling at a variety of spatial and temporal scales. title: Air Pollution Science and Engineering
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5240.
description: This course will cover a variety of topics related to air pollution science and engineering. Topics include: indoor and outdoor air quality (including particulate matters (PM) and gases pollutants); air pollution measurement and statistics; air quality meteorology and dispersion models; principles and challenges of air pollution control and measurement.

title: Urban Climatology
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5260
description: Human modifications to the surface of the Earth during urbanisation change most of the elements of climate and weather in the urban atmosphere. This course introduces the fundamentals of urban climatology and the processes caused by the changes in the surface environment, particularly focusing on how urban structures interact with the atmospheric environment. Numerical modelling and field techniques are introduced to understand the underlying processes resulting urban climatic phenomena. It also examines the implications on human comfort and climate-sensitive urban planning and design, as well as the relationship between cities and climate change.

title: Cloud Dynamics
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5270.
description: This course presents an introduction to the science of clouds. We begin with a descriptive cloud classification to introduce the different types of clouds in the Earth’s atmosphere. The roles of aerosols in cloud are also discussed. This is followed by cloud microphysics, describing the basic microphysical processes regarding formation, growth, shrinkage, breakup and fallout of cloud and precipitation particles. Next, different structures of precipitation and radar cloud sensing are presented. This will then be linked to cloud dynamics, associated with the fluid motions of the atmosphere.
outcome: Students shall learn about a wide variety of physics and dynamics that control the occurrence, characteristics, and behavior of clouds. They shall understand the processes determining all the types of clouds in our atmosphere, over a wide range of spatial scales from microns to thousands of kilometers. They shall appreciate the importance of cloud to Earth’s climate. There are also be opportunities (e.g. outdoor cloud observation, cloud dynamics practicals both computationally and experimentally) where student can practice working effectively in a team, and present information in a clear, concise and logical manner.

Topics may include the structure and function of organic molecules, biogeochemical processes involving organic matter, analytical techniques for studying organic matter, and the role of organic matter in ecosystem functioning. Apply analytical techniques to study organic matter in environmental samples. Evaluate the role of organic matter in ecosystem functioning and environmental quality. Discuss the implications of organic matter chemistry for carbon cycling and nutrient dynamics in natural systems.

description: This course covers the theoretical basis and practical applications of data analysis relevant for earth system science. This course aims to introduce students to Earth and environmental data manipulation, from sampling, reading and writing, to statistical analysis and parameter estimation, to time series analysis, to plotting and visualization. title: Practical Atmospheric Modeling
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5550.
description: This course introduces the basic principles of atmospheric modeling and provides hands-on practice to perform numerical simulations on University computing cluster. It begins with the concept of model and reviewing of physical and chemical processes in the atmosphere. After that, this course will cover introduction and hands-on practice of the three basic processes in atmospheric simulation: pre-processing data, modeling, and post-processing data. The pre-processing process refers to the preparation of data from various sources by different techniques such as the generation of emission inventories for atmospheric chemistry modeling. It then introduces numerical modeling basics such as “model equations and numerical approaches”. For post-processing, this course offers different skills in visualization of the model output and evaluation of model output against real-world observations. This course also introduces advanced knowledge in “model coupling” and “inverse modeling”. Finally, this course provides hands-on practice on simple model development experiments. During the course, we will cover basic Linux environment commands to perform the main tasks mentioned above. Overall, students can anticipate grasping basic modeling concepts and skills from this course, which are of great value to their future careers in both academia and industry.
outcome: Remember and explain the major chemical and physical processes that affect spatiotemporal variations of major atmospheric composition. Explain the basic framework of atmospheric chemistry models including their input and output. Understand what an emission inventory is and be able to pre-process emission inventory for atmospheric chemistry models. Able to compile and run an atmospheric chemistry model. Capable of visualizing model outputs and evaluating model outputs against observations. Have the skills to sort out model structure by reading model codes and then revise model codes according to research needs.

requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences or MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences.
description: Understanding Earth processes and environmental changes requires the experience and skills gained from fieldwork. EESC5709 covers important aspects of field geology, including petrology, structural geology, tectonics, geophysics, and surficial processes. The principal goal of this course is to train students to recognize different lithological units and their spatial relationship in three dimensions, and to understand the related tectonic environment and formation mechanisms. This course will train the postgraduate students to master basic skills of reading and interpreting geological maps, using geological equipment (i.e., compass-clinometer, GPS receiver), and producing field notes and reports. Field projects include field observation and description, techniques for field data acquisition and analysis, sample collection, and geological map compilation. Field projects also focus on surficial processes, which occur over relatively short geological timescales but play important roles in environment and ecology. The field location, whether in mainland China or overseas, may change from year to year.
